trans-unit.source: Creates a search handle, defined by a path and file mask.

seg-source.mrk: Creates a search handle, defined by a path and file mask.

target.mrk: Creates a search handle, defined by a path and file mask.

trans-unit.source: Parameters

seg-source.mrk: Parameters

target.mrk: Parameters

trans-unit.source: The path and file name. (* and ? wildcards accepted - See Remarks)

seg-source.mrk: The path and file name.
(* and ?
wildcards accepted - See Remarks)

target.mrk: The path and file name.
(* and ?
wildcards accepted - See Remarks)

trans-unit.source: Return Value

seg-source.mrk: Return Value

target.mrk: Return Value

trans-unit.source: a search "handle" for use with subsequent FileFindNextFile functions.

seg-source.mrk: a search "handle" for use with subsequent FileFindNextFile functions.

target.mrk: a search "handle" for use with subsequent FileFindNextFile functions.

trans-unit.source: -1 if nothing is found. The value of the @error flag is set to 1 only if the Folder is empty.

seg-source.mrk: -1 if nothing is found.
The value of the @error flag is set to 1 only if the Folder is empty.

target.mrk: -1 if nothing is found.
The value of the @error flag is set to 1 only if the Folder is empty.

trans-unit.source: Remarks

seg-source.mrk: Remarks

target.mrk: Remarks

trans-unit.source: The search string is not case sensitive.

seg-source.mrk: The search string is not case sensitive.

target.mrk: The search string is not case sensitive.

trans-unit.source: Wildcards: In general, * denotes zero or more characters, and ? denotes zero or one character. If your file search string contains only wildcards (or is "*.*"), then see the example below for the return value!

seg-source.mrk: Wildcards:
In general, * denotes zero or more characters, and ?
denotes zero or one character.
If your file search string contains only wildcards (or is "*.*"), then see the example below for the return value!

target.mrk: Wildcards:
In general, * denotes zero or more characters, and ?
denotes zero or one character.
If your file search string contains only wildcards (or is "*.*"), then see the example below for the return value!

trans-unit.source: You can use only one wildcard in the filename part or in the extension part i.e. a*.b?.

seg-source.mrk: You can use only one wildcard in the filename part or in the extension part i.e. a*.b?.

target.mrk: You can use only one wildcard in the filename part or in the extension part i.e. a*.b?.

trans-unit.source: When using a 3-char extension any extension starting with those 3 chars will match, .e.g. "*.log" will match "test.log_1". (not described either in Microsoft documentation).

seg-source.mrk: When using a 3-char extension any extension starting with those 3 chars will match, .e.g.
"*.log" will match "test.log_1".
(not described either in Microsoft documentation).

target.mrk: When using a 3-char extension any extension starting with those 3 chars will match, .e.g.
"*.log" will match "test.log_1".
(not described either in Microsoft documentation).

trans-unit.source: When you have finished searching with the FileFind... functions you must call FileClose() to release the search handle.

seg-source.mrk: When you have finished searching with the FileFind... functions you must call FileClose() to release the search handle.

target.mrk: When you have finished searching with the FileFind... functions you must call FileClose() to release the search handle.

trans-unit.source: Directory name are returned according to the wildcards if any.

seg-source.mrk: Directory name are returned according to the wildcards if any.

target.mrk: Directory name are returned according to the wildcards if any.

trans-unit.source: Due to the underlying Windows API used (FindFirstFile), this function actually searches both the long and short filenames when looking for matches. If you get unexepected results

seg-source.mrk: Due to the underlying Windows API used (FindFirstFile), this function actually searches both the long and short filenames when looking for matches.
If you get unexepected results

target.mrk: Due to the underlying Windows API used (FindFirstFile), this function actually searches both the long and short filenames when looking for matches.
If you get unexepected results

trans-unit.source: then verfiy that it's not the short filename that is being matched.

seg-source.mrk: then verfiy that it's not the short filename that is being matched.

target.mrk: then verfiy that it's not the short filename that is being matched.
